question_text: In a case scenario about cerebellar hemorrhage, what is the next step in management?

options.A: Neurosurgery consultation for evacuation

question_text: An elderly man has a 1-month history of right-sided weakness and confusion. A brain CT shows a crescentic-shaped hypodensity. What is the mechanism of the lesion?

options.A: Bridging veins rupture
patient who was arrested by police presents with encephalopathy and has a halitosis odor. What treatment should be administered?

patient presents with subarachnoid hemorrhage and hyponatremia (serum sodium 129), with a blood pressure of 100 mmHg and high serum and urine osmolarity. What is the significance of these findings? (Note: Incomplete options)
patient with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) two days later has a blood pressure of 170/90 and a marginally low platelet count of 145. What is the next best step in management?
patient with acute stroke received tPA and subsequently developed difficulty with speaking or swallowing. What should be done next?

question_text: What EEG finding is associated with poor prognosis?

options.A: Non-reactive continuous alpha.
56-year-old male patient is found in his house with decreased level of consciousness. He was last seen normal 1 day ago. A brain CT scan is performed. What will you do?

question_text: In a case of trauma, which biomarker is most reliable for detecting disrupted blood-brain barrier (BBB)?

options.A: S100β
patient presents with acute confusion and is found to have elevated blood levels of urea. What is the most likely cause of their symptoms?
patient with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) presents with hyponatremia. What should you do?

patient presents with a headache for months, has papilledema, and an MRI shows hydrocephalus with transependymal edema. What should be done next, considering the presenting symptoms were seizure and confusion?

question_text: An elderly male with left-sided weakness and dysarthria, who is on dabigatran, underwent thrombectomy without receiving tPA. He later has a CT scan showing bleeding. What should be administered to reverse the bleeding?

options.A: Osmotic therapy
patient progressed rapidly to quadriplegia and was intubated. He is awake and following commands with ocular movement, and the MRI is normal. What should be done next?

question_text: An EEG shows a burst suppression pattern. What is the most likely status of the patient?

options.A: Brain dead
patient who is status post cardiac arrest and has been discharged from the hospital returns to the clinic complaining of sudden jerky movements sometimes upon touching. What is your diagnosis?

question_text: Hypertonic saline is contraindicated in which of the following patient populations?

options.A: Patients with end-stage kidney disease

question_text: What is the benefit of using mannitol over hypertonic saline in the management of increased intracranial pressure?

options.A: Less nephrotoxic

question_text: For the same patient, what is the recommended treatment?

options.A: Osmotic therapy
delirious patient presents. What is your next step?
brain CT shows a coup contrecoup injury with left frontal and right temporal bleed. What is the most likely mechanism of injury?

question_text: Alcoholic patient came with post-traumatic seizure and delirium; he was on Keppra and Depakin, then seizure improved. After 2 days, the patient had worsening of his delirium; what will you do?

options.A: Alcohol level
Epidural hematoma (EDH)
patient who has recently delivered vaginally and is experiencing eclampsia presents with progressive flaccid paralysis. What is the next best step in management?
young lady with SLE nephritis on dialysis presents with seizures and confusion. MRI shows high blood pressure with findings consistent with PRES. What is your diagnosis?
